misinformation_claims.claim: Toothpaste is a great spot treatment for acne because it dries out pimples overnight.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Toothpaste contains irritants like menthol, fluoride, and SLS that can cause burns, redness, and worsen inflammation. May lead to contact dermatitis.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Use benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid spot treatments specifically formulated for acne.

misinformation_claims.claim: You don't need sunscreen on cloudy days because UV rays can't penetrate clouds.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Up to 80% of UV rays penetrate clouds. UVA rays (aging/cancer-causing) pass through clouds year-round.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Wear SPF 30+ daily regardless of weather. UV exposure occurs even indoors near windows.

misinformation_claims.claim: Eczema is caused by poor hygiene, so washing more frequently will cure it.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Eczema is an immune-mediated condition related to skin barrier dysfunction, not cleanliness. Over-washing strips natural oils and worsens eczema.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Gentle cleansing once daily, moisturize immediately after, avoid harsh soaps.

misinformation_claims.claim: Expensive skincare products work better than affordable ones because you get what you pay for.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Active ingredient concentration and formulation matter, not price. Many drugstore products contain identical actives to luxury brands.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Check ingredient lists for proven actives like retinoids, vitamin C, niacinamide at effective concentrations.

misinformation_claims.claim: Lemon juice is a natural and safe way to lighten dark spots and hyperpigmentation.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Lemon juice is highly acidic (pH 2) and phototoxic. Can cause chemical burns, post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation, and increased sun sensitivity.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Use dermatologist-recommended treatments: vitamin C, niacinamide, azelaic acid, or prescription hydroquinone.

misinformation_claims.claim: Hot water and steam open pores and help cleanse skin more deeply, which is good for rosacea.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Pores don't open/close. Hot water and steam are major rosacea triggers that cause flushing and worsen inflammation.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Use lukewarm water for cleansing. Avoid heat triggers. Keep skincare routine gentle and minimal.

misinformation_claims.claim: Natural and organic products are always safer and better for your skin than synthetic ones.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Natural doesn't equal safe. Poison ivy is natural. Many people are allergic to natural ingredients like essential oils, botanical extracts.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Both natural and synthetic ingredients can be safe or irritating. Choose based on skin type and sensitivities, not marketing terms.

misinformation_claims.claim: Scrubbing your face hard with exfoliants will get rid of acne faster by removing dead skin.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Physical over-exfoliation damages skin barrier, increases inflammation, and triggers more oil production. Can worsen acne and cause scarring.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Gentle chemical exfoliation (BHA/AHA) 2-3x weekly is more effective than harsh scrubbing.

misinformation_claims.claim: Psoriasis is just dry skin, so any heavy moisturizer will cure it.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Psoriasis is an autoimmune condition causing rapid skin cell turnover. Moisturizers help symptoms but don't treat underlying cause.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Requires medical treatment (topical steroids, vitamin D analogs, biologics). Moisturizers are supportive, not curative.

misinformation_claims.claim: Once you treat melasma and dark spots disappear, they won't come back.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Melasma is chronic and hormonally driven. Sun exposure, hormones, and heat can trigger recurrence even after successful treatment.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Requires ongoing maintenance with sunscreen, gentle skincare, and sometimes continued use of treatment ingredients.

misinformation_claims.claim: If a product stings or burns, it means it's working and penetrating deeply into your skin.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Stinging/burning usually indicates irritation or damaged skin barrier, not efficacy. Can lead to sensitization and long-term damage.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Effective products should not cause pain. Mild tingling from some actives is normal, but burning is a warning sign.

misinformation_claims.claim: You should save retinol for when you're older because using it too early will make it stop working later.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Skin doesn't build tolerance that makes retinoids ineffective. Starting retinoids in 20s-30s prevents aging better than waiting.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Retinoids are safe and beneficial starting in mid-20s. Consistent use provides cumulative benefits without tolerance issues.

misinformation_claims.claim: Drinking lots of water will hydrate your skin and cure dryness.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Drinking water supports overall health but doesn't directly hydrate skin surface. Skin hydration requires topical products and intact barrier.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Use humectants (hyaluronic acid, glycerin) and occlusives (ceramides, petrolatum) for skin hydration. Adequate water intake supports health but isn't a skincare solution.

misinformation_claims.claim: Oily skin doesn't need moisturizer because it already produces enough oil.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Oil and hydration are different. Dehydrated oily skin overproduces oil to compensate. Skipping moisturizer can worsen acne.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Use lightweight, non-comedogenic moisturizers. Proper hydration can actually reduce excess oil production.

misinformation_claims.claim: You need to get some sun exposure without sunscreen to produce enough vitamin D.
misinformation_claims.why_false: Vitamin D can be obtained through diet and supplements. Unprotected sun exposure increases skin cancer and aging risk significantly.
misinformation_claims.correct_info: Get vitamin D from fortified foods, supplements, or incidental sun exposure. Always wear sunscreen for intentional outdoor time.

usage_guidelines.placement: Insert between turns 2-4 for realistic flow
